raw_text:
No seasonal lift for house market
 
 A swathe of figures have provided further evidence of a slowdown in the UK property market.
 
 The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), British Bankers Association (BBA) and Building Societies Association (BSA) all said mortgage lending was slowing. CML figures showed gross lending fell by 4% in November as the number of people buying new homes fell. Elsewhere, the BBA added underlying mortgage lending rose by £4m in November, compared to October's £4.29m. The CML said that loans for new property purchases fell 25% year-on-year to 85,000 - the lowest total seen since February 2003.
 
 Data from the CML showed lending fell to just over £25bn in November, from £25.5bn a year earlier. Separate figures from the Building Societies Association showed the value of mortgage approvals -- loans agreed but not yet made -- stood 32% lower than at the same time last year, at a seasonally-adjusted £2.98bn. The figures come hot on the heels of new data from property website Rightmove which suggested owners must indulge in a "winter sale" and slash prices by up to 8%. Miles Shipside, commercial director at Rightmove, said sellers would have to be "more realistic with their asking prices" to tempt buyers. The average asking price of a home fell by more than £600 from £190,329 in November to £189,733 in December, while the length of time it takes to sell a home rose to 81 days from 53 in the summer.
 
 Rightmove said estate agents were set to enter 2005 with a third more properties on their books than a year ago. "Even once the quieter holiday period is over, sellers will find themselves competing with a lot of other properties on the market. In any business, excess supply and low demand means one thing - cut prices," Mr Shipside said.
 
 "The proof is that some properties that have been appropriately discounted are selling, even in the current market." Overall, asking prices have fallen 3.3% from their July peaks as the equivalent of £6,500 has been cut from an average property. A host of mortgage lenders and economists have predicted that property prices will either fall or stagnate in 2005. "What is apparent is a picture of a slowing market, but one that should remain stable as we return to more normal volumes of lending over 2005 as a whole," CML director general Michael Coogan said. "It's a fairly consistent picture, showing that mortgage demand has fallen back again, which is consistent with a continuing correction in the housing market," Investec economist Philip Shaw said. "However, the figures do suggest only a modest weakening, and we stand by our view that the property market will remain in the doldrums for some time, though a collapse is still unlikely."
llama3.2:1b:
Here is a summary of the text in plain text:

* UK house market slowdown
* Mortgage lending fell 4% in November, with new home purchases declining
* BBA data shows underlying mortgage lending rose by £4m
* CML figures show gross lending fell to £25bn in November
* Rightmove data suggests sellers must cut prices and properties are selling quickly
* Estate agents expect a third more properties on their books than last year
llama3.2:3b: UK mortgage lending slowed in November with gross lending falling 4% year-on-year to its lowest level since February 2003.
The number of new home purchases also fell by 25%, leading to a decrease in the value of mortgage approvals and asking prices for homes, which have fallen 3.3% from their peaks.
gemma2:2b: Mortgage lending is slowing in the UK market.
New home sales have decreased, asking prices are falling, and there's a rise in supply of properties.
This has led to predictions of price declines or stagnation in 2005.
While the market is slowing down, it remains stable overall with consistent trends pointing towards more moderate conditions.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The UK property market has slowed, with mortgage lending falling to £25bn, leaving fewer people buying new homes.
Rightmove data showed an increase in home sales due to a winter sale and price cuts, but asking prices have fallen 3.3%.
The property market will remain in the doldrums for some time, though a collapse is unlikely.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The UK house market shows signs of slowing with mortgage lending decreasing and home sales falling off as buyers opt to sell during winter.
qwen2.5:3b: No seasonal lift has been observed in the UK house market with mortgage lending falling 4% in November compared to year-ago levels.
The Council of Mortgage Lenders reports that new home purchases fell by 25% year-on-year to its lowest since February 2003, totaling 85,000 loans.
Additionally, data from the Building Societies Association shows mortgage approvals have dropped 32% year-over-year.
Rightmove suggests sellers must reduce their prices for buyers due to a winter sale, with average home asking prices dropping by more than £600 from August.
Analysts predict either falling or stagnating property prices in 2005, as lending demand continues to decline despite some stabilization expected throughout the year.
opencoder:1.5b: The summary of the provided text presents an analysis of a slowdown in the UK property market.
The figures highlight a decrease in mortgage lending, which has been observed since the CML.
The data from the BBA and CML suggest that loans for new property purchases have fallen year-on-year to a minimum level, as well as from previous years.
Additional data from the Building Societies Association (BSA) suggests an improvement in the value of mortgage approvals.
The figures also highlight the effect on owners' buying behaviour during a "winter sale".
The Rightmove website mentioned that estate agents were set to enter 2005 with a third more properties than a year ago, hinting at a possible return to market stability.
smollm:1.7b: The UK property market has been experiencing a slowdown in recent months, with mortgage lending slowing down significantly.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), British Bankers Association (BBA) and Building Societies Association (BSA) all agree that the current state of the market is characterized by a slowdown in new home purchases and a decrease in mortgage lending.
The CML, BBA, and BSA have all provided data showing that mortgage lending has slowed down significantly over the past few months.
The CML reported that gross lending fell by 4% in November compared to October's figure of £25bn.
Similarly, the BBA said that loan approvals for new property purchases fell by 32% year-on-year to £189,733 in December from £206,233 in November.
The BSA added that the value of mortgage approvals stood at 25% lower than at the same time last year.
The data suggests that there is a lack of new buyers for properties, which has contributed to the slowdown in the market.
This is supported by the fact that the average asking price of a property has fallen by 3.3% from its July peak to £189,733.
A host of mortgage lenders and economists have predicted that the UK property market will either fall or stagnate in 2005 as we return to more normal volumes of lending over the next year.
However, it is worth noting that some properties that were appropriately discounted are still selling at current prices.
This suggests that there may be a degree of flexibility in the market and that prices may not necessarily reflect the underlying fundamentals of the property market.
Overall, the data suggests that the UK property market has entered 2005 with a slowdown in new home purchases and a decrease in mortgage lending.
While there is still some room for growth, it is unlikely that the market will continue to grow at this pace over the next year.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: A slowdown in the UK property market has been supported by data showing mortgage lending activity is declining.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), British Bankers Association (BBA), and Building Societies Association (BSA) have reported that mortgage lending is slowing, with net lending decreasing by 4% in November due to a decline in home buyers.
The BBA noted an increase in underlying mortgage loans rose by £4m compared to October's £4.29m.
Lending for new property purchases fell 25% year-on-year to 85,000 units since February 2003.
Rightmove data shows sellers must reduce prices by up to 8%, especially during the winter.
The average asking price of homes decreased by over £600 from £190,329 in November to £189,733 in December, with the sell time rising to 81 days.
Lenders like CML director general Michael Coogan stated the market is slowing but should stabilize now.
Lenders predict a fall or stagnation in prices by 2005, supported by Investec economist Philip Shaw who noted modest weakening but remains cautious about collapse likelihood.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), British Bankers' Association (BBA), and Building Societies Association (BSA) have reported that mortgage lending fell by £4 million in November, compared to the previous month.
This was a slowdown in the UK property market, with some forecasts predicting that prices will either fall or stabilize in 2005.
However, economist Philip Shaw of Investec believes that the market remains weak and predicts a continuation of a slower correction.
The figures also show an increased number of lending applications, suggesting that buyers are being more realistic with their asking prices.
Despite this slowdown, the overall asking price has fallen 3.3% since July's peak levels, indicating that property prices will remain stable.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Although there has been a slight slowdown in the UK housing market, the swathe of figures provided by the Council of Mortgage Lenders, British Bankers Association, and Building Societies Association (BSA) all suggest that mortgage lending is continuing to dive.
Gross lending fell by 4% in November, with underlying lending rising by £4m over the month, according to the CML figures.
The BBA added a 25% increase to lending, while the CML noted a dip in new mortgage loan approvals from 17,000 per month in February to just over 8,000 in November.
Meanwhile, data from the Building Societies Association showed a 32% decline in loans approved for construction.
The figures come as anecdotal evidence shows sellers are likely to cut their asking prices by up to 8%.
This means potential home buyers are facing steeper competition when it comes to securing a property.
phi:2.7b: The UK property market has been slowing down, with mortgage lending falling, house purchase numbers decreasing and asking prices dropping.
Property sales may require sellers to cut prices to attract buyers.
Estate agents are expected to have more properties on their books in 2005.
Overall, asking prices have fallen by 3.3% from their July peaks.
However, the market is not expected to completely collapse, with mortgage demand falling but still remaining stable.
orca-mini:3b: The UK property market has slowed down with the number of people buying new homes falling, as shown by the figures from the CML, BBA, and BSA.
Lending for mortgage purchases fell 25% year-on-year, while the value of mortgage approvals dropped by more than £600 and the time it takes to sell a home rose to 81 days from 53 in the summer.
Some properties have been appropriately discounted but are still selling, even in the current market.
The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), British Bankers Association (BBA) and Building Societies Association (BSA) all said mortgage lending was slowing.
Miles Shipside, commercial director at Rightmove, said sellers would have to be "more realistic with their asking prices" to tempt buyers.
Overall, asking prices have fallen 3.3% from their July peaks as the equivalent of £6,500 has been cut from an average property.
hermes3:3b:
UK house market slowing: 
Mortgage lending falls by 4%, lowest new home purchases since 2003
Property owners must cut prices up to 8% due to increased competition
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The UK property market slowed down in November according to the Council of Mortgage Lenders, British Bankers Association, and Building Societies Association.
Gross lending decreased by 4% and mortgage lending rose £4m compared to October.
The number of people buying new homes fell to 85,000 – the lowest total since February 2003.
Data from the CML showed lending falling to just over £25bn in November.
Rightmove suggested that estate agents will have a third more properties than a year ago in 2005 and asked prices decreased by 8%.
Despite predictions of property prices either falling or stagnating in 2005, mortgage lenders and economists believe the market will remain stable as volumes of lending return to normal levels.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The UK property market is slowing, with mortgage lending declining according to figures from the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), British Bankers Association (BBA), and Building Societies Association (BSA).
CML data shows gross lending fell 4% in November, and loans for new property purchases dropped 25% year-on-year to the lowest level since February 2003.
Mortgage approvals were also down 32% compared to the previous year.
Property website Rightmove reported that sellers must lower prices to attract buyers, with average asking prices falling and homes taking longer to sell.
Estate agents are entering 2005 with a surplus of properties, leading to further price reductions.
Experts predict that property prices will either fall or stagnate in 2005, with the market expected to remain slow but stable rather than collapsing.
stablelm2:1.6b: The UK property market is experiencing a slowdown as per Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), British Bankers Association (BBA) and Building Societies Association (BSA).
Gross lending by CML fell 4% in November while underlying mortgage lending rose by £4m, compared to the previous month.
The number of people buying new homes also decreased by 4%.
The BBA mentioned that underlying mortgage lending had increased by £4m in November, from October's £4m increase.
The CML reported loans for new property purchases dropped 9% year-on-year to 125,0..
The average asking price of a home fell by more than 3% from the previous month, and the length of time it takes to sell a home rose to 8 days in December compared to 6 days in summer.
The average asking price has fallen 3.3% from its peak in July at £179,000.
Some properties that have been appropriately discounted are selling in the current market.
Most mortgage lenders and economists predict that property prices will either fall or stagnate in the near future.
However, CML's director general Michael Coogan said the market should remain stable as they return to more normal lending volumes over time.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The UK house market experienced a slowdown in November 2004, according to data from the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), British Bankers Association (BBA), and Building Societies Association (BSA).
Gross lending fell by 4% compared to October, with new property purchases dropping 25% year-on-year.
Loan approvals for new properties were 32% lower than the previous year, at £2.98bn.
Rightmove reported a decline in average home asking prices by over £600 and an increase in time to sell from 53 to 81 days.
Estate agents anticipate more properties as they enter 2005, indicating a potential need for price reductions due to excess supply and low demand.
Experts predict property prices will either fall or stagnate in 2005, with a stable market expected over the year.
